data.title: When Real Books Inspire Fake Books
data.meta_description: Whether retroactively penned by adoring fans, postmodern literary pranksters, or the original authors themselves, imaginary books have a way of eventually making their way into reality, evolving from two-dimensional plot props into real publishedâ¦
data.text:
Whether retroactively penned by adoring fans, postmodern literary pranksters, or the original authors themselves, imaginary books have a way of eventually making their way into reality, evolving from two-dimensional plot props into real published tomes. Although weâve already made a wishlist of reads we wish fictional characters would write â and indeed over in TV-land, characters from Mad Menâs Roger Sterling to Californicationâs Hank Moody have also had their fictional volumes published on this side of the screen â here are five real books that exemplify literary life imitating fictional art.

The Amazing Adventures of the Escapist

Conceived by Brooklynite Sam Clay and his Czech refugee cousin Joe Kavalier, The Escapist symbolizes both the youthful imagination of its fictional creators and the era of early comic book superheroes in which itâs based. Although this superhero figure was invented for Michael Chabonâs 2000 novel The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier and Clay, itâs hard to distinguish this masked vigilante from other contemporaneous icons like Superman and the Phantom. After Chabon received the Pulitzer Prize for his novel, he asked comic vets like Will Eisner and Howard Chaykin to bring the imaginary character to life in a series of real-life comics, which have since been published in multiple separate volumes.

The Book of Counted Sorrows

Frequently quoted in Dean Koontzâs novels, The Book of Counted Sorrows was considered a mysterious and rare poetry tome for years. But after Koontz began receiving up to 3,000 letters a year inquiring about his reference source, the mega-selling author announced: âThere is no such book. I made it up. The way you made up footnote sources for fabricated facts in high-school English reports.â Koontz eventually penned a volume of poetry under the same title, which he has since released in suitably limited quantities to maintain its elusive allure.

Hamster Huey and the Gooey Kablooie

Fans of Calvin and Hobbes will recognize the title Hamster Huey and the Gooey Kablooie as the name of Calvinâs favorite bedtime book. Although Bill Watterson intended the story as a background piece that would remain within the comic strip itself, Mabel Barr turned it into a real childrenâs book about overcoming bullies and learning respect for others. Itâs hard to imagine a troublemaker like Calvin begging for such a morally upright tale every night â or Watterson sanctioning the bookâs publication, for that matter â but this is nonetheless the realization of a supposed childhood favorite.

Venus on the Half Shell

First mentioned in Kurt Vonnegutâs 1965 novel God Bless You, Mr. Goldwater, Kilgore Trout is an itinerant, financially bereft science fiction writer who also appears in other Vonnegut staples like Slaughterhouse-Five and Breakfast of Champions. Although this struggling character finds little success in his fictional life, Troutâs oft-referenced novel Venus on the Half Shell was pseudonymously written in 1974 and published under the fake authorâs name. Though initially attributed to Vonnegut himself, the bookâs real author was later revealed to be Philip Jose Farmer.

The Tales of Beedle the Bard

The Tales of Beedle the Bard first appeared as a mentioned collection of fairy tales within the Harry Potter books, but, after the oh-so-lucrative series ended, J.K. Rowling decided to expand her Potterverse by bringing this second-hand referenced book to life. Featuring five apparently classic fairy tales for wizard children, The Tales of Beedle the Bard features an introduction by fictional entity/Hogwarts headmaster Albus Dumbledore, who contextualizes the stories within their âhistoricalâ epoch, as well as hand-drawn illustrations by Rowling herself.
